{{Computer form factors}}
'''Pico-ITX''' is a PC [[motherboard]] form factor announced by [[VIA Technologies]] in January 2007 and demonstrated later the same year at [[CeBIT]]. The formfactor was transferred over to [[SFF-SIG]] in 2008. The Pico-ITX form factor specifications call for the board to be 10 Ã 7.2 cm (3.9 Ã 2.8 in), which is half the area of [[Nano-ITX]]. The processor can be a [[VIA C7]], a [[VIA Eden]] V4, a [[VIA Nano]] or any other that uses VIA's NanoBGA2 technology for speeds up to 1.5 GHz, with 128KB [[L1 cache|L1 & L2 caches]]. It uses [[DDR2]] 400/533 [[SO-DIMM]] memory, with support for up to 1[[Gigabyte|GB]]. Video is supplied via [[AGP]] by VIA's [[UniChrome]] Pro II [[GPU]] with built-in [[MPEG-2]], [[MPEG-4|4]], and [[WMV9]] decoding acceleration. The [[BIOS]] is a 4 or 8 [[Mbit]] Award BIOS.<ref>[http://www.linuxdevices.com/news/NS9265074155.html "Pico-ITX goes "stackable""]</ref><ref name="VIA Pico-ITX Whitepaper">[http://www.via.com.tw/en/downloads/whitepapers/initiatives/spearhead/pico-itx_form_factor.pdf VIA Pico-ITX Whitepaper]</ref><ref name="VIA EPIA PX Series Homepage">[http://www.via.com.tw/en/products/mainboards/motherboards.jsp?motherboard_id=472 VIA EPIA PX Series Homepage]</ref>
== EPIA PX == [[Image:Top EPIA PX10000G Motherboard new.jpg|thumb|Top view of the EPIA PX10000G, Rev B.]] [[Image:Bottom EPIA PX10000G Motherboard new.jpg|thumb|Bottom view of the EPIA PX10000G, Rev B.]]
=== PX10000G ===
The first motherboard that was produced in this form factor is called [[EPIA]] PX10000G. It is 10 Ã 7.2 cm (3.9 Ã 2.8 in) and 10 layers deep. The [[operating temperature]] range is from 0[[Â°C]] to about 50Â°C. The [[Humidity#Effects_on_electronics|operating humidity level]] (relative and non-condensing) can be from 0% to about 95%. It uses a 1 GHz VIA C7-M processor, a VIA [[VIA_chipsets#Embedded|VX700]] chip set, and is [[RoHS]] compliant.
It has onboard [[Video Graphics Array|VGA]] video-out, VIA VT6106S 10/100 [[8P8C]] [[Ethernet]], [[UDMA]] 33/66/100/133 44-pin [[AT Attachment|PATA]] (1x), and [[Serial ATA|SATA]] (1x) [[I/O]]. [[Digital Visual Interface|DVI]] and LVDS video-out, [[USB 2.0]], [[COM (hardware interface)|COM]], [[PS/2 connector|PS/2]] Mouse & Keyboard, and [[HD Audio|HD]] 5.1 channel audio (supplied by a VIA VT1708A chip) are supported through the usage of I/O pin headers and add-on modules/[[daughter card]]s.<ref name="VIA Pico-ITX Whitepaper"/><ref name="VIA EPIA PX Series Homepage"/><ref>[http://e-itx.com/via-epia-px-px10000g-pico-itx-motherboard.html E-ITX PX10000G Product Page]</ref>
It has been demonstrated running [[Microsoft]] [[Windows XP]] and [[Windows Vista]]. Modern versions of major [[Linux]] distributions, including [[Fedora (operating system)|Fedora Core]] 6 and [[Ubuntu (operating system)|Ubuntu]] 7.10, will also run on it.<ref>[http://www.linuxdevices.com/news/NS2154184680.html "Via's incredible shrinking mobo line spawns "pico-ITX""]</ref>
=== PX5000 ===
This model is similar to the PX10000G, but uses the 500 MHz [[VIA Eden]] [[ultra low voltage|ULV]] CPU.
There are two versions of this model, the PX5000G, which has an active (fan-assisted) heatsink, and the PX5000EG, which has a passive (fanless) heatsink.
=== Add-on Modules ===
''(Note: Either the VIA PX-O add-on module or 4 USB 2.0 I/O are supplied in retail packages.)''
The VIA PX-O daughtercard supplies access to: *1 [[RCA connector|RCA]]-out for [[S/PDIF]] usage *4 USB 2.0 ports *1 3.5mm Mic-in, 1 3.5mm line-out, 1 3.5mm line-in *1 buzzer/speaker *1 CN9 connector (function TBC) *1 CN10 connector (function TBC).<ref>[http://www.mini-itx.com/reviews/pico-itx/default.asp?page=1 mini-itx.com Review: "VIA EPIA PX10000 Pico-ITX Review"]</ref>
<!--- More information needed on the VT1625M add-on module! * Is the external TV-out RCA or S-Video? * Same question for the video capture. * Can the PX-O & VT1625M cards be used in tandem/at the same time? --> The VIA VT1625M daughtercard supplies access to: *1 external TV-out *1 video capture port.<ref name="VIA EPIA PX Series Homepage"/>
The Serener PXFPIO (also labeled under VIA PX-DIO) is 109mm Ã 22mm in size and connects via a 120mm ribbon cable through a daughter card. This addon may require modification to the heatsink due to the size of the daughter card. It supplies access to: *power & reset switches *3.5mm audio in/out *S/PDIF-in *power & HDD activity LEDs *4 USB 2.0 ports <ref>[http://www.logicsupply.com/products/pxfpio Serener PXFPIO Product Page]</ref><ref>[http://www.mini-itx.com/store/?c=39#pxdio mini-itx.com VIA PX-DIO Product Section]</ref>
The VIA PX-TC daughter card, compatible with the PX10000G only, is designed to enhance the multimedia capture and output. It supplies access to: *1 S-Video port *1 video-in port *1 [[YPbPr]] port *1 S/PDIF-out <ref>[http://www.logicsupply.com/products/px_tc PX-TC Product page]</ref>
== EPIA-P700 ==
The second motherboard series in this form factor, the P700 series improves upon the PX10000G series by offering a [[Gigabit Ethernet]] (Using the VIA VT6122 chipset) or a 10/100 Ethernet adaptor (VIA VT6107) as a manufacturing option, integrating the power adaptor (allowing for direct +12V DC-In & enabling it to directly power SATA), and making the Ethernet & VGA ports optional via the P700-A daughter card.
Expanded functionality is offered via the following pin I/O: *1 LAN *1 VGA/DVI *1 COM Port *1 Audio pin connector for Line-out, Line-in, MIC-in *1 Front panel *4 USB 2.0 *1 PS2 mouse/keyboard *1 LVDS *1 LPC/SM Bus/GPIO (Unusable due to VIA not releasing a GPIO driver)
The EPIA-P700-10L has a 1 GHz VIA C7 CPU.
The EPIA-P700-05LE has a 500 MHz VIA Eden ULV CPU and has a passive heatsink.
=== Add-on Modules ===
The P700 comes retail with the P700-A & P700-B daughter cards.<ref>[http://edageek.com/2008/06/27/via-epia-p700/ "Difference between A/B daughtercards."]</ref>
The P700-A supplies: *Gigabit Ethernet *1 VGA port *1 COM port *DVI port via I/O cable
The P700-B supplies: *4 USB 2.0 ports *1 Buzzer *1 Line-out, 1 Line-in, 1 MIC-in (3.5 mm)<ref>[http://www.via.com.tw/en/products/mainboards/motherboards.jsp?motherboard_id=690 VIA EPIA-P700 Series Homepage]</ref><ref>[http://linuxdevices.com/news/NS9886731599.html "Pico-ITX board bears twins"]</ref>
==Intel based products== Even though the form factor was introduced by [[VIA Technologies]], there are also boards available based on [[Intel]] [[processors]]. Some have the [[CPU]] and the [[chipset]] directly on the Pico-ITX board. Other boards, like the Toradex Daisy, allow the addition of Nano COM Express modules.<ref>[http://www.windowsfordevices.com/c/a/News/Toradex-Daisy-supports-Toradex-Robin "Credit-card-sized COM gets carrier board"]</ref>
== Pico-ITXe == {{main|Pico-ITXe}}
The [[Pico-ITXe]] specification adds on to the Pico-ITX formfactor by taking the EPIA-P700 and upgrading the chipset to a [[VIA_chipsets#Embedded|VX800]], doubling the maximum RAM to 2 GB, allowing for 667/533 SO-DIMM RAM, upgrading the GPU to VIA's [[UniChrome#Chrome9|Chrome9]] HC3, and adding support for [[SUMIT]]. Another notable addition is the expansion from 10 to 12 layers thickness.
